title: Friday, 11th December, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE

Hi! Hello. Good morning. Hey.

BE

ML switched itself off at around 11.15am and didn't come back until well after midday.

BE

We've sorted the problem though.

11:03 am
BE

BE

He's running full speed now, so fingers crossed for today's session.

undefined
11:04 am
BE

And where to we begin? It's another bad day.

BE

No sign of that Santa rally we talk about every bloody year.

BE

FTSE off 1% at pixel, down 63 points at 6024

11:05 am
BE

Anything South African is getting hammered

BE

Though we'll come back to those later.

BE

Because first up, can we take a quick trip into the fascinating semantic intricacy of Plus 500?

11:06 am
Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 432.75, up 18.75 (+4.53%), High: 439.75, Low: 426.00, Volume: 123.56k
BE

Here's today's statement.

BE

Plus500 notes recent inaccurate external comments and confirms that Plus500UK is not subject to regulatory restrictions including preventing it from onboarding new customers. The Company therefore wishes to clarify that following the strengthening of the UK management team, both the Group and UK Boards intend that Plus500UK resumes the onboarding of new customers in January 2016.

11:06 am
BE

So.

BE

"Recent inaccurate external comments" sounds interesting, right?

BE

I asked the flack this morning which they were.

11:07 am
BE

Reply: "This refers to a note circulated by Numis on Tuesday."

BE

Which some might think a bit strange.

BE

Here's what Numis wrote on Tuesday.

11:07 am
BE

Although management state they are not currently under any regulatory "restrictions", we wonder why Plus500UK is still unable to accept new clients. Perhaps the master plan is to redirect all European clients to Cyprus, close the UK subsidiary and avoid the FCA?

BE

As in, the Numis note doesn't suggest Plus is "subject to regulatory restrictions including preventing it from onboarding new customers."

BE

In fact, Numis is speculating the exact opposite.

11:08 am
BE

It speculated that though Plus has been unrestricted by the FCA, it was still preferring customers to sign up via its Cyprus portal.

BE

That makes the first sentence of Plus's statement a non-sequitur.

BE

It "confirms" something that was never suggested.

11:10 am
BE

Now, perhaps we should overlook this kind of thing. And normally we would.

BE

But Plus doesn't have the best of records for clear communication.

BE

That was the main reason Numis cited for dropping coverage on Tuesday, the implication being, how do you research a company when you can't trust what it says?

11:12 am
BE

There was the strange inclarity on whether Plus was issued with a 166 Notice, for instance.

BE

Anyway, we note today's statement. We also note its nonsensicality. And then we move on.

undefined
11:13 am
BE

So, sell SA.

Old Mutual PLC (OML:LSE): Last: 159.60, down 14.6 (-8.38%), High: 171.50, Low: 158.40, Volume: 14.19m
Investec PLC (INVP:LSE): Last: 429.70, down 40.2 (-8.56%), High: 462.60, Low: 427.60, Volume: 1.91m
11:13 am
Mondi PLC (MNDI:LSE): Last: 1,279, down 37 (-2.81%), High: 1,307, Low: 1,272, Volume: 971.08k
BE

And, as if you needed another reason .....

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 308.10, down 10.55 (-3.31%), High: 321.30, Low: 304.95, Volume: 4.33m
11:14 am
BE

Rand's still in freefall

BE

Which you can argue is good for the local miners, given it'll lower their costs

BE

Petra, for instance.

11:15 am
Petra Diamonds Ltd (PDL:LSE): Last: 63.51, down 2.04 (-3.11%), High: 65.70, Low: 62.90, Volume: 567.66k
BE

Which is down on in spite, also, of a reasonably promising auction result.

BE

Special pink goes for $10.2m

11:17 am
BE

Anyway, in terms of the financials, it's still difficult to get a handle on what the rand weakness will do.

BE

Old Mutual's a spectacularly complicated beast, for instance, so the numbers aren't easy to calculate in a hurry.

BE

Instead, due to yesterday's tech fail, I didn't get the chance to share this RBC note on Solvency II

11:18 am
BE

Which is really interesting, so I'll do it today instead.

BE

Basically, the restrictions on moving cash out of South Africa mean a lot of OML's surplus capital disappears from the new ratio calculations.

BE

Here's RBC. I reiterate, yesterday. But still worth reading.

11:19 am
BE

Old Mutual has indicated that the introduction of Solvency II will likely
result in a lower coverage ratio than under the current capital Financial
Groups Directive (FGD) framework. With a ratio of 149% at end of Sept
2015 (surplus £1.5bn) which was weaker than June 2015 (surplus £1.7bn)
and our expectations, this will likely place it towards the lower end of
peer group. FGD assumes full fungibility of capital across geographies
while exchange control means the surplus under Solvency II within the
South African business will be capped. In addition, Old Mutual will
use the standard formula for its South African business, which is more
conservative than the internal models most insurers will use.

BE

The capping of the South African surplus means the absolute Solvency II
ratio will be low but it will not be volatile. In addition the ability to remit
dividends to the holding company which determines the ability to pay the
group dividends may likely be unaffected. Despite this we believe investors
will focus on absolute Solvency II ratios in the early days of the regime
(as they did when Basel III for banks was introduced) and will prefer the
stronger capitalised insurers.

BE

Old Mutual is complex – the dual listed group sells life, property and
casualty, banking and asset management product in several geographies
(South Africa, Rest of Africa, UK, Asia, Latin America, US). We believe the
UK business will be separately listed, we see this at least three years away
as it would not achieve a full valuation yet. OML is in the early stages of
bringing together its asset manager (OMGI), its advice business Intrinsic
(acquired July 2014) and its wealth manager Quilters (acquired February
2015). In addition OML should be well placed to gain share in the UK
savings market now that no one is required to buy an annuity; however,
these pensions freedoms only began in April 2015. The pensions freedoms
provide it with an opportunity to pick up assets that would previously have
been used to buy annuities, which OML does not offer. We have lowered
our price target 10%, 5% for lower earnings and 5% for a lower multiple.

11:20 am
BE

This is hopefully not too small to read.

BE

undefined
11:22 am
BE

And on the broader picture re South Africa .....

BE

... I'll default to Deutsche Bank, which has always had one of the best SA teams.

BE

South Africa: What now?

11:23 am
BE

What are the ratings implications, possible timelines and key issues to look out
for?
Rating agencies can step out of predetermined schedules with a ratings review
during times of emergency. The latter is not clearly defined but this could be such
an occasion if market conditions become chaotic. From a fiscal perspective, we
need direction on implications for fiscal policy. They (ratings agencies) probably
need some direction or statement to corroborate that policy changes will not
occur. We are unsure of the new minister's position on inflation targeting.
Effectively the October budget had cemented the medium term fiscal framework.
If these matters are not confirmed anytime soon by the new minister himself, or
some senior figure, there will be negative repercussions. The risks are still around
whether there is any reprioritisation of budgets, with a populist slant, such as
condoning spending where Nene gave pushback. Whether the expenditure
ceilings remain intact is a critical signal for the agencies. Another litmus test will
be whether NT can raise the offshore loan it has been planning for this fiscal year.
It will most likely postpone coming to market over the next few months and tap
the dollar reserves for its required funding needs if it has to. There are sizeable
offshore redemptions next year too, so how it manages this will be important.
Moody's confirmed it needed to review these matters and the same probably
applies to the other agencies.

BE

Are there implications for SARB policy actions?
Exchange rate moves will probably dictate SARB actions, but the severity of the
current sell-off in a thin liquidity environment makes an emergency rate meeting
highly probable. If so, these actions will not be with mild intentions. Capital
outflow risks are heightened by Fed risk, and broader EM exit fears, so the SARB
could plausibly wait until January to review matters as they unfold. Even this has
its problems given SARB's concerns about having to play catch up if it waits. No
doubt there are action plans in place to provide liquidity if needed. There is no limit
on what the level on the rand must be in these markets to spur the SARB into
action. But the quantum of the rand's adjustment post the Fed meeting will
possibly galvanise selloff momentum if the tone of the Fed adds to EM asset
repricing risks. No doubt the rand's move up to now has already been of concern,
hence the hike in November. All-in-all idiosyncratic currency moves are of great
concern to the SARB as it is a policy mandate to protect the intrinsic value of the
rand.
Collectively, last night's actions have negative consequences for the rand and
possibly the credit. The forecast deterioration in the rand's momentum from
R15.40/USD at the end of 2016 and R15.7/USD before this week's events now
looks optimistic. Moreover, more extreme adjustments to the policy rate by the
SARB (in quantum) may become necessary if this selloff continues. An emergency
policy meeting is highly probable.

BE

Danelee Masia is the economist there.

11:24 am
undefined
BE

I note the "bored of miners" comment on the right .... well, tough.

BE

Because we have a Lonmin rights issue conclusion.

11:25 am
BE

71% takeup.

BE

So the rest is getting marketed to non-shareholders, as the underwriters desperately try to relieve themselves of the stick.

Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 0.96, down 0.07 (-6.80%), High: 1.00, Low: 0.92, Volume: 24.81m
11:26 am
BE

A reminder of why the 29% here represent the more rational approach.

BE

BMO ......

BE

 The lacklustre support for Lonmin indicates a possible market apathy for PGM stocks in what remains a challenging market.
 On our estimates, Lonmin's rights issue keeps it going for a couple of years if current PGM price levels are maintained, providing some breathing space to restructure operations.
 Other PGM producers are possibly in a more difficult position on our estimates, but ultimately current PGM prices
suggest that high cost shafts needs to be suspended across all producers.
 With nationwide local elections set for the middle of 2016, there may be significant political opposition to closing mines and job losses, making for a challenging operational environment for all of the PGM producers.

11:27 am
BE

So basically, we're left with a 7.847bn share overhang

BE

On an issue price of 1p

BE

In a share trading at 0.95-0.96p.

11:28 am
BE

Avoid. Keep avoiding.

undefined
BE

Brief break from miners .......

11:29 am
BE

To stop over at Morrison

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 139.51, down 1.39 (-0.99%), High: 141.60, Low: 139.30, Volume: 2.93m
BE

Though it's a non story, we're pretty confident.

11:30 am
BE

http://www.investe...1512110826007764I/

BE

Some excitement this morning when Deutsche Bank suddenly became Morrison's biggest shareholder, going from non-disclosable to nearly 11%.

BE

11:30 am
BE

It's innocuous though.

BE

Not a dawn raid or anything interesting like that.

BE

Seems there's a new disclosure regime that's recently come into force

11:30 am
BE

Meaning banks have to roll together all their CFD exposures and disclose them as one gigantic position.

BE

Underlying, we're confident that nothing whatsoever has changed.

BE

I'm told to expect quite a few of these kind of statements in the coming days.

11:31 am
BE

And unless there's a good reason not to ignore them, ignore them.

undefined
BE

And apologies once again for yesterday's tech failure.

11:32 am
BE

In the meantime, what else do we have?

BE

There was the interesting timing of yesterday's statement from International Personal Finance.

International Personal Finance PLC (IPF:LSE): Last: 254.80, down 67.7 (-20.99%), High: 318.10, Low: 230.00, Volume: 5.95m
11:33 am
BE

Flagging up the potential for more regulatory flux in Slovakia

BE

IPF's already had no shortage of regulatory flux in Poland, its biggest market.

BE

It's not too surprising, incidentally, that IPF doesn't attract much attention. The doorstep lending industry doesn't usually get a positive press.

11:35 am
BE

But I guess IPF operates quite far away.

BE

RBC takes us through what the risks are here.

BE

l Just prior to the market close, IPF issued a statement indicating revisions to consumer legislation in Slovakia which “would have a material adverse financial impact on its Slovak business” if the legislation were to become effective in its current form. Management hosted a conference call at the market close to discuss the statement.

l Yesterday (9-Dec-15), a “previously undiscussed proposal” to amend various pieces of consumer legislation was tabled in the Slovak Parliament, and was passed. The proposed amendments are changes which prohibit separate contracts for “ancillary” services. This includes services such as the collection of loan
repayments in a customer's home, and therefore captures IPF’s home collection charge. Additionally, new clarification of the existing cost cap is included in the legislation, which states that the cap applies to all costs connected with a loan, whether mandatory or not. The current level of the cap is 27% of the issue value per annum.

11:36 am
BE

l IPF’s most popular product in Slovakia is a 60 week loan. IPF currently charges 32% per £100 issued in interest costs and administrative charges (the interest rate is 27% per annum pro-rated for 60 weeks) and in addition, charges 56% on the £100 issued for the home service charge. Under the proposed changes, the home service charge would be prohibited. Therefore, per £100 issued for 60 weeks, IPF’s revenue would decline from £88 to £32, which is a 64% decline. IPF discloses that in the 12 months to 30-Jun-15, its Slovak business generated revenues of ~£43MM, and PBT of ~£6MM (Czech and Slovakia are reported as one operation in IPF’s financials). We estimate that Slovakia constitutes ~5% of total revenue and ~5% of total PBT.

l On the conference call, management also indicated a ban on delivering loans through non-personalized pre-paid cards, which is how IPF currently delivers loans in Slovakia. Cards must now either be personalized, or IPF could revert to its previous practice of delivering loans through third-parties (i.e. via bank account or postal order).

l The draft law will now go to the Prime Minister for formal signature and then to the President for approval. Once received, the President has 15 days to either sign the legislation into law or to exercise his right of veto.  We note that all the MPs who voted in favour of the amendment were from the ruling party, while the President is from the opposi on party. Were  the President  to  veto  the legislation, it would most likely be returned to a session of Parliament in Q1/16 and  if a  majority of  MPs  voted again  in favour, there would  be  no opportunity for the President to veto it a second  me. According to the current draft of the legislation, it would become effective immediately on publication following signature by the President. It would not apply retrospec vely.   

l Management admitted that these amendments to the consumer legislation were unexpected. They indicated that they will devote efforts to lobbying to overturn these changes and proposing ways for the business to cope with the changes, although they acknowledged it is too early to say what these measures could entail.

BE

(@FJP: so you're a buy-to-let investor and a former loan-shark investor?)

BE

Conclusion: If the legislation enters force as currently proposed, we believe that management would need to reassess the viability of its Slovakian operation. While we
acknowledge that Slovakia is only a small part of IPF’s business, after the recent negative regulatory changes in Poland, we believe that today’s announcement reinforces that the regulatory headwinds faced by IPF are not close to abating and in our opinion should continue to cause uncertainty around the stock.

11:38 am
BE

And Caz.

BE

 Pricing structure. The most popular product in IPF’s Slovakian lending
market is the 60-week loan. The interest charges pertaining to such a
loan equate to 32%, while the home servicing costs are 56%, giving a
total charge of 88% for their overall services. These home servicing
charges would be removed with the potential implementation of the new
cap. We note there is a potential mitigating fee of c15% which IPF could
apply to late payments, but clearly this would not offset the loss of the
home servicing fee.

BE

 Potential shift towards a digital offering. In the event the new rules
were to be implemented and the home collection service was to be
prohibited, we believe IPF would need to consider a different strategy for
Slovakia to ensure the economic viability of the business or perhaps be
faced with having to consider closing the business. We believe one
potential option would be to move towards a digital offering as the agent
model would no longer be appropriate. Such a transition would likely
take some time as management would need to pilot whether a digital
offering would work in Slovakia; hence, we believe there would be at
least a temporary impact on profitability.

11:39 am
BE

 Valuation. Whilst valuation does not look expensive, with share trading
on FY16E P/E of 10x, we view potential earnings risk to the downside
reflecting regulatory uncertainty. Consequently, we struggle to see any
near-term catalysts for the stock.

undefined
BE

Now just five risers on the FTSE board.

11:41 am
BE

In a session that's likely to lack much good news from the US later

BE

Could turn out to be a bleak day.

BE

Let's plod on though.

11:42 am
BE

To oil, perhaps.

BE

And I'd like to blame this Premier Oil selloff on a Merrill downgrade

Premier Oil PLC (PMO:LSE): Last: 51.14, down 6.02 (-10.52%), High: 56.30, Low: 50.70, Volume: 3.82m
11:43 am
BE

But Merrill also upgrades Tullow, which is .....

Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 166.40, down 10.7 (-6.04%), High: 178.00, Low: 165.50, Volume: 3.13m
BE

Let me find the note anyway.

11:44 am
BE

E&P 2016.

BE

Theme # 1: 2016, the year of capital injections
Hedges rolling off over 2016 will be a final precursor to balance sheet capital injection,
either via equity or asset sales: conventional debt, with yields in the space up to 15-20%
is effectively shut. The European E&P space is trading at decade high leverage multiples
(average net debt EBITDA 3-4x) and cash operating costs (incl. maintenance capex) are
averaging over US$40/boe – not sustainable if oil remains at current levels over a longer
period. Tullow, Premier Oil, EnQuest and GKP are most leveraged plays in the space.

BE

Theme # 2: Major FID Projects likely to be delayed
The most exposed stocks to this theme continue to be minority partners in capital
intense developments. With a high cost of capital, one of the biggest NPV detractors of
value is time itself. Meanwhile, with 2016 sanction dates, in our view, see delays:
Premier Oil/Rockhopper (Sea Lion), Ophir (Fortuna LNG), Tullow Oil/Africa Oil (South
Lokichar) and (by end-16) Genel Energy (Miran). We further push out the assumed start
up dates for each of the above, causing NPV’s for affected stocks to fall up to 10%.

11:44 am
BE

Theme # 3: Light at the end of the tunnel for M&A?
Recent months has seen a flurry of M&A related newsflow in the European E&P space.
As the industry adjusts to a new macro lower-for-longer context (incl. narrower asset
bid-ask spreads), we expect to see increased opportunistic corporate activity. We believe
the main beneficiaries within European Oils are to be found within the E&P space,
where average company share prices are implying oil prices as low as US$50/boe and
the spread to M&A transaction values continues to open up. Material asset bases are the
focus here: Lundin, Genel Energy, DNO and Tullow Oil.

BE

Theme # 4: Opex cuts take longer to materialise than capex
Whilst almost all investor focus over the year has been on capex reductions (on average
30% reduction in FY15 v FY14), we believe the next industry focus point will be opex:
standardisation, operating efficiency (uptime) and more industry sharing. Early signs of
progress were seen from EnQuest at its Capital Markets Day, which showed the one of
the high cost producer cutting opex y-o-y around 25%. Others could follow suit.

BE

So Tullow to neutral, which is an upgrade, and DNO, Premier and Oryx to underperform, which are downgrades.

11:45 am
BE

Merrill's house view is $50 Brent, $48 WTI.

BE

At least until supply-demand resets.

BE

Eventually, a steadier USD and shrinking supply/demand imbalances should push Brent to an average $61/bbl in 2017.
The estimate cuts come on the back of an expectation of weak growth, weak inflation and strong dollar continuing into 2016. As our strategists expect EM growth to remain below trend and the Chinese yuan to depreciate against the USD, the macro dynamics will
remain a major headwind.
But global oil inventories are exceptionally high (Chart 4). The US could be the first region to start experiencing supply/demand rebalancing now on a sharp shale oil output decline (our commodities team sees an outright non-OPEC contraction of 750kb/d in 2016), with Brent-WTI differentials narrowing to an average $2/bbl next yea

11:46 am
BE

The graph is awesome.

BE

BE

Sure. Why not. That'll do. Whatever.

11:47 am
undefined
BE

Okay, I'm getting bombarded with Dow-Dupont flashes and can't make sense of them immediately.

BE

*DOW CHEMICAL TO BECOME 100% OWNER OF DOW CORNING
*DUPONT & DOW CHEMICAL TO COMBINE IN ALL-STOCK MERGER
*DOWDUPONT TO SEEK SEPARATION INTO 3 PUBLIC COMPANIES

11:49 am
BE

I think it's one of those merger of equals subsidiary buyout three-way split stories.

BE

Imagine the fees!

BE

Just trying to remind myself where we were on this one. Think the WSJ had it a few days ago.

11:50 am
BE

As in, via Credit Suisse .....

BE

The Three Companies: We believe the combination will split up
into an Agriculture company, a Specialty Materials company
(including Electronics & Solar, Consumer Solutions, DD's Safety &
Protection business, etc.) and a Commodity/Plastics company
(including DOW and DD Plastics and Materials businesses). Each
business would be a top-tier platform with the Ag business
generating ~$18.6bn in sales (based on 2014 sales), the
Commodities business generating ~$50.1bn and the Specialty
business generating ~$24.1bn.

BE

Synergies: At these levels of revenues, companies in the space
typically see 6-8% of cost synergies, implying ~$4.5-6bn in cost
savings. That being said, the savings relative to revenues in the
plastics business could be at the lower end given where we are in
the commodity cycle (about mid-cycle). Additionally, given that the
new entity will be broken into three companies, we estimate the
incremental cost/dis-synergies would likely be ~$300-400mm (cost
of putting in 3 corporate structures vs. the existing two).

11:51 am
BE

Taking that into consideration, the cost synergy potential is likely in the ~$4-
5bn range (we believe the $3bn from the press comments, while a good
starting point, will prove to be too conservative long-term). In the long-term we
also believe there will be revenue synergies, particularly in the ag platform as
DOW's products are better leveraged across the Pioneer sales force. We
believe the largest opportunity remains in the Americas (all inclusive) and see
some potential for the seed platform (specifically traits; note the base genetics
biz may require divestitures due to Americas' market share overlap).

BE

Regulatory Issues: While there is some overlap in DOW and DD's
businesses, we believe that any divestitures will likely be modest. The Ag
business has some overlap in the crop protection chems (we believe the likely
place we will see some divestitures is in herbicides).

BE

Value Creation: A transaction of this magnitude has integration risk around
synergies (putting two large cap companies into one combined entity and
subsequently breaking it up into three separate companies). However,
assuming management can successfully integrate the businesses and we are
right regarding synergies, we believe investors could conservatively see
significant value creation of ~$35-40bn (or ~28-32% of the pre-announcement
market cap of the two companies) before accounting for the incremental
growth/revenue opportunities created through the combination.

11:51 am
BE

Actual details may be identical to that, or not. I haven't looked, and am too behind on the story to catch up while on air.

undefined
BE

*DUPONT SEES PRETAX CHARGE ABOUT $780M, SEES 10% JOBS AFFECTED

11:53 am
BE

.... which would seem to square with the analysis above.

BE

@R7039275: doubt it. I have actual work to do.

BE

@erlkin: Murph's checked in today to say he's still ill. He might be around next week.

11:55 am
BE

FTSE getting worse. Down 1.2% at pixel.

BE

Multi-year lows on Barclays, Burberry, Tesco, Pearson ....

BE

On Capita, @FJP, the statement looked okay to me.

11:56 am
Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 1,166, down 17 (-1.44%), High: 1,200, Low: 1,164, Volume: 1.03m
BE

Outlook unchanged in spite of rather unsurprising end-market weakness.

BE

On a different day, it'd be flat to up.

11:58 am
BE

Jefferies' Kean Marden is always worth reading. Here he is.

BE

Capita’s year end trading statement was mixed. Despite a slightly smaller bid
pipeline, management’s comments regarding FY16E organic revenue growth
were more upbeat than expected and 5% consensus could be exceeded if the
UKAR bid is successful. Bears will focus on the portfolio review, as exiting
non-core businesses will boost group margins and ROCE by c40bp and c50bp,
respectively but at this stage targets for both variables remain unchanged.
FY15E trading is in line with expectations. Capita is on track to deliver 4% organic
(JEFe 4.2%) and low double digit reported (JEFe 11.4%) revenue growth despite softer recent market conditions in specialty nursing/supply teacher staffing. OpFCF conversion will be c100% in FY15E (JEFe 100%).

BE

More positive than expected FY16E LFL comments. The statement stresses that
organic growth will accelerate in 2016 and on the conference call management confirmed
this would still be the case if Capita doesn’t win the large UK Asset Resolution mortgage
administration contract that will be awarded in January (sufficient to add 2.5% to FY16E
LFLs). This suggests that 5-6% consensus is achievable even though the group currently
has visibility over only 1%. Contributory factors include: potential Q1 contract awards start
rapidly; Life and Pensions contracts won’t be a headwind as guaranteed price step downs
ceased in mid-2015; 40% of revenue isn’t driven by converting the bid pipeline into new
contract wins but rather by cross selling services to existing customers (particularly in the
Asset Services division).

11:58 am
BE

Several contracts awards are likely in H1. The bid pipeline has declined from £5.4bn
in August to £5.1bn but should expand in 2016 post the UK government’s comprehensive
spending review. The announcement contains a small contract win – a £62m/7 year
contract to provide customer management services to Unitymedia. Forthcoming decisions
include the UK Asset Resolution mortgage administration contract in January, where Capita
and Computerserve are down to the final two, which would contribute £120m to FY16E
turnover. In addition, a swathe of contracts will be awarded in January/February including:
a German opportunity with £20-30m annual revenue (which could be 2-3x larger if full
outsourcing option is taken); an unspecified European opportunity (with £20-30m annual
revenue); an undisclosed UK CRM contract. Two additional German opportunities will be
awarded in Q2.

BE

Non-core exit could boost group margins and ROCE by c40bp and c50bp,
respectively. Capita has reviewed “a number of small profitable or low growth businesses
which lack strategic fit” and the carrying value of the Insurance division intangible. During
the conference call, management revealed that some contracts have been exited and some
units will be divested in 2016. In aggregate, they were break even on £100-200m revenue
in FY15E but ranged from “some of our most profitable” to loss making. Further detail
will be provided at the February prelims but our initial calculations suggest that exit could
boost group margins and ROCE by c40bp and c50bp respectively versus management’s
12.5-13.5% margin and 14-16% ROCE targets.

BE

And apologies for the lumpy formatting there.

11:59 am
undefined
BE

On Choo, I've been asking.

Jimmy Choo PLC (CHOO:LSE): Last: 112.60, up 6.6 (+6.23%), High: 114.14, Low: 100.00, Volume: 2.73m
12:00 pm

BE

Order book volume's less than 200k on an average price of 105p

BE

As for Aldermore ... we've having tech troubles again .....

12:04 pm
BE

I'll attempt to paste but it might take a moment or two.

Aldermore Group PLC (ALD:LSE): Last: 212.60, down 14.1 (-6.22%), High: 227.90, Low: 208.00, Volume: 577.73k
BE

Here's that Deutsche note, which is pinned to the Basel directives on BTL

12:05 pm
BE

And which we should've mentioned earlier, had I remembered.

BE

We downgraded Aldermore to Hold two weeks ago when the UK government
announced an increase in the stamp duty by 3% for BTL mortgages. This
followed additional powers being given to the FPC on BTL, and tax changes
over the summer. Today we see a further headwind for Buy-to-let lending in
the UK: updated proposals for standardized credit risk, which suggest
increasing risk weights to at least 70% for resi property where repayment is
materially linked to cashflows generated by the property. We think these
changes would reduce CET1 by c.230bps if implemented. Our TP falls to 240p.

BE

Today the Basel Committee published its second consultative document on
‘revisions to the standardized approach for credit risk’. Risk weight proposals
for mortgages are changed: with a discrimination between owner-occupier and
BTL being introduced. For BTL properties with LTV sub 60%, risk weight would
be 70%, for 60-80% LTV, RW would be 90%, and for over 90% LTV, RW of
120%. This compares with 35% risk weight for residential mortgages at
Aldermore (and other banks using standardized risk weights). With a BTL
average LTV of 62% at 1H15, clearly there could be a material increase in the
risk weight on this portion of the book. Elsewhere owner occupier changes
should be immaterial, we think, and we see some scope for Aldermore to
benefit from new CRE risk weightings. But overall the BTL impact would see
CET1 ratio fall 230bps to 9.7% from 12% at 1H15, or 130bps / £50m below the
company’s 11% CET1 target. The company could fill this shortfall over time via
retained earnings, but this would come at the expense of growth.

12:05 pm
BE

Aldermore is trading at 1.5x 2016E TNAV, 9.2x 2016E EPS. We value the bank
on a Gordon Growth Model using 2018E ROTE, a cost of equity of 12% and
assuming a 3% sustainable growth rate. We then discount back to get our 12-
month target price. We have included a £50m capital deficit in our valuation to
cover the potential shortfall from regulatory changes around BTL (as covered in
this note). As a result, our TP falls from 267p to 240p. Given 6% upside to the
current share price we retain our Hold Rating. Key upside risks: stronger BTL
growth than expected, relaxation of regulatory tax regime, more resilient
asset pricing than expected, regulatory impact less significant than expected.
Key downside risks: Though the bank need only attract a small fraction of the
market to achieve its growth targets, compressing asset spreads are a key risk.
Higher-than-expected credit losses and rising term deposit costs as rates rise
are also key risks, as are changes to the regulatory tax regime in the UK,
regulatory impact more significant than expected.
